Package frc.robot.util.hyperdrive.util

Class PositionTracker

  • java.lang.Object
    • frc.robot.util.hyperdrive.util.PositionTracker
  • public class PositionTracker
extends java.lang.Object
    A class that tracks the position of the robot in field space. Because team 3695 has not had experience with swerve drive as of yet, this class is primarly programmed for tank bots.

    This class relies on the integrity of the drivetrain encoder readouts to calculate the robot's position on the field. Those encoder counts must be as close as possible to the actual displacement of the wheel from its starting position. That being said, in order for this class to accurately report the robot's true position on the field, the drivetrain wheels cannot drift. Drifting will result in a difference betweenthe encoder position and the drivetrain's actual position, which will cause this class to inaccurately report the robot's position.

    • Constructor Detail

      • PositionTracker

        public PositionTracker​(double motorUnitsPerUnit,
                       double x,
                       double y,
                       double heading)
        Creates a new PositionTracker.
        Parameters:
        motorUnitsPerUnit - The number of "motor units" that are present in a single unit of distance (inches, meters, etc). This should be the same value that was passed into the Hyperdrive constructor.
        x - The starting X-coordinate of the robot.
        y - The starting Y-coordinate of the robot.
        heading - The starting heading angle of the robot in degrees. (0 = towards positive X. Positive = CCW)

      • PositionTracker

        Parameters:

      • zeroPositionAndHeading

        public void zeroPositionAndHeading​(boolean waitForEncoders)
        Zeroes the position and heading of the robot. This should be called when the robot is NOT moving.
        Parameters:
        waitForEncoders - True if the drivetrain is also currently being zeroed. This option is necessary because of the lag that is experienced when performing a CAN operation. An encoder zero operation will not instantly result in zero encoders. In fact, the encoder value will most likely not read 0 until the next robot frame. Enabling this option forces this method to wait until the either class is fed a position value that is close enough to zero, or until a half-second has passed.

      • zeroPositionAndHeading

        public void zeroPositionAndHeading()
        Zeroes the position and heading of the robot. This is equivelent to calling zeroPositonAndHeading(false).

      • update

        public void update​(double driveDistance,
                   double movementDirection)
        Updates the position of the robot using a distance travelled and heading travelled in. If the Hyperdrive class is present, this method should not be called. Call one of Hyperdrive's update() methods, and this will be called by those.

        It is recommended that this method is called in one of the robot's periodic() methods. While is is possible to call this method in a while loop in some separate thread, programmers should be careful of how often they request encoder counts from their motor controllers to avoid overloading their CAN network, which can cause undesired motor behavior.
        Parameters:
        driveDistance - The displacement of the robot since the last zero, in encoder counts.
        movementDirection - The direction in which the robot is moving.

      • getPositionAndHeading

        public Point2D getPositionAndHeading()
        Returns the current position and heading of the robot.
        Returns:
        Position and Heading of the robot.
